name: civic_virtue
description: The Civic Virtue Framework is a specialized implementation of the Narrative Gravity Map methodology, designed to evaluate the moral architecture of persuasive political discourse. It maps narratives along five core dipoles representing tensions between integrative civic virtues and disintegrative rhetorical forces.

primary_sources: Sandel, M. (2012). What Money Can't Buy: The Moral Limits of Markets.
Putnam, R. (2000). Bowling Alone: The Collapse and Revival of American Community.
theoretical_foundation.theoretical_approach: Draws from classical virtue ethics and contemporary civic republican theory to identify moral dimensions that strengthen or weaken democratic discourse and civic engagement.

analysis_instructions: Evaluate how the text demonstrates civic virtues versus disintegrative rhetorical forces across five core dipoles: Identity, Integrity, Fairness, Aspiration, and Stability.

coordinate_system.description: Circular coordinate system emphasizing virtue-vice opposition through vertical clustering

positioning_strategy.description: Wells clustered around vertical axis to emphasize moral hierarchy between integrative virtues (top) and disintegrative forces (bottom)

top_cluster.description: Civic virtues clustered around 90° (top) representing constructive democratic forces

bottom_cluster.description: Civic vices clustered around 270° (bottom) representing destructive democratic forces

dipoles.name: Identity
dipoles.description: Moral worth and group membership dynamics in democratic discourse
dipoles.theoretical_context: Central tension in democratic theory between universal human dignity and group-based identity claims that can either strengthen or undermine pluralistic democracy.

positive.name: Dignity
positive.description: Affirms individual moral worth and universal rights, regardless of group identity. Emphasizes agency, pluralism, and character over affiliation.
positive.rich_description: Dignity represents the civic virtue of recognizing inherent human worth across all group boundaries. It manifests in discourse that treats individuals as moral agents capable of reasoning and choice, rather than as representatives of demographic categories. This well captures appeals to universal human rights, individual character development, and shared civic capacity that transcends particular identities.

recognition_patterns: Affirming individual worth regardless of background
Focusing on character and actions over identity markers
Defending individual rights against group pressure

negative.name: Tribalism
negative.description: Prioritizes group dominance, loyalty, or identity over individual agency. Often frames moral worth in in-group/out-group terms.
negative.rich_description: Tribalism represents the civic vice of subordinating individual moral worth to group membership and loyalty. It manifests in discourse that treats people primarily as representatives of demographic categories rather than as individual moral agents. This well captures appeals that define moral and political worth through group membership, create rigid in-group/out-group boundaries, and demand loyalty to group identity over shared civic principles.

recognition_patterns: Defining people primarily by group membership
Demanding loyalty to group over principles
Using group membership to determine credibility

exclusion_markers: threats to our way of life

dipoles.name: Integrity
dipoles.description: Truth-telling and information transparency dynamics in democratic discourse
dipoles.theoretical_context: Essential foundation for democratic deliberation requiring intellectual honesty, evidence-based reasoning, and transparent communication to enable informed citizen decision-making.

positive.name: Truth
positive.description: Demonstrates intellectual honesty, admits uncertainty, engages with evidence and opposing views.
positive.rich_description: Truth represents the civic virtue of intellectual honesty in public discourse. It manifests in communication that prioritizes accuracy over persuasion, acknowledges complexity and uncertainty, and engages genuinely with evidence and opposing perspectives. This well captures appeals to empirical evidence, admission of limitations, and transparent reasoning processes that enable democratic deliberation.

negative.name: Manipulation
negative.description: Distorts information or exploits emotion to persuade without transparency or consistency.
negative.rich_description: Manipulation represents the civic vice of distorting information and exploiting emotion for persuasive advantage. It manifests in communication that prioritizes winning over truth, conceals relevant information, and uses deceptive framing to bypass rational deliberation. This well captures appeals that mislead through selective evidence, emotional manipulation, conspiracy theories, and deliberate obfuscation of facts.

recognition_patterns: Using fear appeals to bypass reasoning

conspiracy_promotion: they don't want you to know

dipoles.name: Fairness
dipoles.description: Justice and grievance handling dynamics in democratic discourse
dipoles.theoretical_context: Democratic societies require mechanisms for addressing wrongs and distributing benefits that maintain both moral legitimacy and social cohesion over time.

positive.name: Justice
positive.description: Advocates impartial, rule-based fairness; forward-looking and inclusive in addressing wrongs.
positive.rich_description: Justice represents the civic virtue of impartial fairness that strengthens democratic institutions and social trust. It manifests in appeals to universal principles, due process, and institutional reform that addresses systemic problems while maintaining equal treatment. This well captures approaches to wrongdoing that seek restoration and improvement rather than revenge or zero-sum redistribution.

recognition_patterns: Supporting procedural fairness over outcome preferences
Seeking institutional solutions to systemic problems

negative.name: Resentment
negative.description: Centers on grievance and moral scorekeeping, often zero-sum; defines fairness through punishment or reversal.
negative.rich_description: Resentment represents the civic vice of defining fairness through grievance and moral scorekeeping that undermines social cohesion and democratic trust. It manifests in zero-sum thinking about justice where one group's gain requires another's loss, emphasizing punishment over restoration and historical grievance over forward-looking solutions.

recognition_patterns: Defining justice as group payback or reversal
Emphasizing historical wrongs over future solutions
Creating moral hierarchies based on suffering
Treating politics as zero-sum group competition
Rejecting universal principles for group preferences

dipoles.name: Aspiration
dipoles.description: Future orientation and goal-setting dynamics in democratic discourse
dipoles.theoretical_context: Democratic societies require realistic hope and achievable goals that motivate collective action while acknowledging genuine challenges and trade-offs.

positive.name: Hope
positive.description: Offers grounded optimism with realistic paths forward. Admits difficulty but affirms human and institutional potential.
positive.rich_description: Hope represents the civic virtue of grounded optimism that inspires democratic participation while acknowledging real challenges. It manifests in discourse that offers realistic paths toward improvement, admits difficulty and trade-offs, but maintains confidence in human and institutional capacity for positive change through collective effort.

recognition_patterns: Emphasizing gradual rather than revolutionary change

negative.name: Fantasy
negative.description: Denies trade-offs or complexity; promises simple or utopian outcomes without credible strategy.
negative.rich_description: Fantasy represents the civic vice of unrealistic promise-making that undermines democratic accountability and rational policy-making. It manifests in discourse that denies genuine trade-offs, promises perfect solutions, or advocates magical thinking that avoids the difficult work of democratic compromise and gradual improvement.

recognition_patterns: Promising perfect solutions without acknowledging costs
Denying the need for difficult choices or trade-offs
Advocating revolutionary change without realistic transition plans
Using magical thinking to avoid policy complexity
Creating unrealistic expectations about change pace
Rejecting incremental progress in favor of total transformation

dipoles.name: Stability
dipoles.description: Threat assessment and adaptive response dynamics in democratic discourse
dipoles.theoretical_context: Democratic societies require balanced threat assessment that enables appropriate responses without undermining deliberative capacity or individual rights through fear-based mobilization.

positive.name: Pragmatism
positive.description: Emphasizes evidence-based, adaptable solutions with attention to feasibility and unintended consequences.
positive.rich_description: Pragmatism represents the civic virtue of evidence-based problem-solving that strengthens democratic governance through realistic assessment and adaptive response. It manifests in discourse that acknowledges genuine challenges while maintaining proportionate responses, emphasizes trial-and-error learning, and adapts strategies based on evidence rather than ideology.

recognition_patterns: Proposing solutions proportionate to actual problems
Building in mechanisms for course correction
Learning from both successes and failures

negative.name: Fear
negative.description: Focuses on threat and loss, often exaggerating danger to justify reaction or control.
negative.rich_description: Fear represents the civic vice of threat exaggeration that undermines democratic deliberation and proportionate response. It manifests in discourse that amplifies dangers beyond realistic assessment, uses crisis framing to bypass normal democratic processes, and mobilizes anxiety to justify extreme measures or emergency powers.

recognition_patterns: Using crisis language to bypass normal deliberation
Mobilizing fear to justify extreme measures
Creating urgency to prevent careful consideration
Framing every challenge as existential threat

weighting_philosophy.description: Three-tier weighting system based on moral psychology research emphasizing identity as the primary driver of political behavior
weighting_philosophy.theoretical_foundation: Based on research showing identity-based appeals are most powerful in political discourse, followed by universalizable moral principles, with cognitive reasoning processes having tertiary influence

primary.description: Identity forces - most powerful moral motivators in political discourse
primary.justification: Research in political psychology shows identity-based appeals are the strongest predictors of political behavior and attitude formation

secondary.description: Universalizable principles - fundamental moral claims that transcend particular identities
secondary.justification: Moral principles that can be applied across contexts and groups, secondary to identity but still powerful in shaping discourse

tertiary.description: Cognitive moderators - abstract reasoning processes that influence how other appeals are processed
tertiary.justification: Cognitive and emotional frameworks that moderate how identity and moral appeals are received and processed

prompt_configuration.expert_role: You are an expert political analyst specializing in civic virtue and democratic discourse with deep knowledge of moral psychology, virtue ethics, and persuasive narrative analysis in democratic contexts.
prompt_configuration.analysis_focus: Evaluate how political narratives morally orient toward universal human agency and public trust versus grievance, fear, and identity-based appeals that can strengthen or weaken democratic discourse and civic engagement.
prompt_configuration.scoring_emphasis: Focus on the moral architecture of persuasive discourse - how the narrative constructs relationships between individuals, groups, and civic institutions rather than on specific policy positions or partisan alignment.
prompt_configuration.evidence_requirements: Provide specific textual evidence supporting each well score, explaining why certain themes dominate over others. Quote directly from the text and explain how language patterns reflect deeper moral frameworks.

key_analytical_questions: How does this narrative construct individual moral worth - through universal dignity or group membership?
What relationship to truth and evidence does the narrative establish?
How does the narrative frame justice - as impartial process or group-based grievance?
What kind of hope does the narrative offer - grounded optimism or unrealistic fantasy?
How does the narrative handle uncertainty - through pragmatic adaptation or fear-based reaction?
contextual_considerations: Consider the civic implications of moral claims - do they strengthen or weaken democratic institutions?
Evaluate whether appeals transcend or reinforce group boundaries
Assess whether the narrative enhances or diminishes capacity for democratic deliberation
Consider long-term effects on civic trust and engagement
common_analytical_challenges: Distinguish between legitimate group solidarity and exclusionary tribalism
Separate pragmatic truth-telling from partisan spin
Differentiate between principled justice claims and resentment-based grievance
Identify the difference between realistic hope and wishful thinking
Recognize when fear appeals are proportionate versus manipulative

com.name: Center of Mass
com.description: Weighted center position considering signed weights, indicating overall civic orientation

nps.name: Narrative Polarity Score
nps.description: Distance from center normalized by circle radius, indicating strength of civic orientation

dps.name: Directional Purity Score
dps.description: Consistency of integrative vs disintegrative pull, indicating coherence of civic message
